title: Für Elise

musicalLanguage.description: Beethoven's Bagatelle No. 25 in A minor (WoO 59), universally known as Für Elise. One of the most recognizable piano pieces ever written. The gentle, lilting A section contrasts with a more forceful middle section before returning home.
musicalLanguage.structure: Rondo: A-B-A-C-A. The A theme is the famous E-D#-E motif. B section moves to F major/C major. C section is a dramatic descent in A minor.
keyMoments: Resolution to A minor chord in measure 4 — the first moment of rest
Left hand provides gentle bass-note-chord accompaniment throughout the A section
Measure 9: the theme repeats — Beethoven builds familiarity before departing
The B section shifts to C major and then G7, creating warmth before returning
teachingGoals: Right hand legato playing — smooth connection between the semitone oscillation (E-D#) and the descending line
Left hand arpeggiated accompaniment pattern: bass note followed by chord tones
3/8 time feel — three eighth notes per measure, gentle waltz-like pulse
Dynamic control — the A section should be soft and singing (pp to p)
Pedaling: light sustain pedal, changing with each harmony change
styleTips: Play the opening motif tenderly, not mechanically — it's a sigh, not a scale
The D#-E semitone should feel like longing, not exercise
Keep left hand quieter than right — it supports, never dominates
Slight ritardando before each return of the A theme
The piece is intimate — imagine playing for one person in a small room

measures.teachingNote: The famous opening — three eighth notes, E-D#-E. This is a pickup measure (anacrusis). Play softly and let the notes sing. The D# creates the tension that defines the whole piece.
The motif continues oscillating — D#-E-D# — building suspense before the descent. Keep the same soft, singing tone.
Now the melody descends: E down to B, then up to D. This is the turn — we're heading toward the resolution. The B4 is the lowest point of the motif.
C resolves down to A — the first real arrival on the tonic. Left hand enters here for the first time with the bass A and E. A moment of gentle rest.
Right hand begins the answering phrase — E4 and A4 outline the A minor chord. Left hand provides the bass foundation.
B4 in the right hand over E major harmony in the left (E-E-G#). This is the dominant — it wants to return to A minor.
Right hand outlines E major (E4-G#4) over the bass E. The dominant chord preparing to resolve.
B4 hangs above the A minor bass — this is the half cadence. We're ready to hear the theme again.
The pickup into the theme's return — E4 leaps up to D#5, launching back into the iconic motif.
The theme returns. Same E-D#-E motif, same tenderness. Beethoven gives the listener the comfort of recognition.
This time, instead of G#4, the right hand plays C5 — the melody is heading somewhere new.
B4 resolves down to A4 — a perfect authentic cadence in A minor. The A section closes. First complete musical thought.
Pickup into the B section — the mood is about to shift. E4 leaps up to E5.
But no — Beethoven brings back the A theme one more time. The rondo form means we'll hear this motif many times, each return a homecoming.
Second complete cadence in A minor. Now the B section truly begins.
B section begins in C major — a bright shift from A minor. The left hand plays a warm C major arpeggio while the right hand steps up C5-D5.
E5 sings over the C major harmony — this is the emotional peak of the B section. Let it ring.
Shift to G major (dominant of C). Right hand descends D5-C5 over the G major arpeggio.
B4 rests over G major — a half cadence in C major. The music pauses to breathe.
Suddenly E major returns — the dominant of A minor. Beethoven is pulling us back to the home key.
B4 rises to E5-D#5 — and there it is, the start of the main theme growing out of the B section. Seamless transition.
The A theme returns once more — like an old friend. This is the rondo: departure and return, tension and release.
Final cadence. The piece settles into A minor one last time. Let the last A4 fade naturally — don't rush the ending.

source: Arrangement: AI Jam Session. Based on Beethoven's Bagatelle No. 25 in A minor, WoO 59.
